poem:
**Deep Freeze Rhapsody**

Chilled cathedral hums of frost,  
glassy whispers in the night,  
peas and chips, an icy host,  
beneath that dimly flickering light.  
Fish fingers, ancient, breaded past,  
sleep in their frozen, timeless bed,  
while mushrooms yearn for better cast—  
in cold spaces, dreams are fed.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Freeze your nuts – but not your mushrooms! 28 thrifty, fabulous ways to use your freezer Almost all of us have a freezer of some size, and yet so few of us maximise its potential. If you’re like me, it’s sat there filled with nothing more than a bag of peas, a half full sack of oven chips, a tray of ice cubes and some pre-pandemic fish fingers. But it’s always on, always consuming energy.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
